One-pot synthesis of porous carbon nanospheres supported CuPd alloy catalysts for the hydrogenation-dechlorination of 2,3,6-trichloropyridine Wanqi Zhang Writing – original draft Validation Software Methodology Formal analysis Data curation 1 Jiakang Liu Writing – review & editing Validation Software Resources Formal analysis 1 Maoling Pan Visualization Software Methodology Formal analysis Kun Huang Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Project administration Investigation Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China Normal University, 500N, Dongchuan Road, Shanghai 200241, China School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China Normal University 500N, Dongchuan Road Shanghai 200241 China School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China Normal University, 500N, Dongchuan Road, Shanghai 200241, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Wanqi Zhang and Jiakang Liu equally contributed to this study. Hydrogenation-dechlorination to produce 2,3-dichloropyridine is important for the next-generation pesticides. In this work, we successfully synthesized porous carbon nanospheres supported CuPd alloy nanoparticles via a simple and efficient one-pot strategy. Furthermore, by adjusting the Cu/Pd ratio and carbonization temperature, the obtained Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 showed the highly catalytic activity for the hydrogenation-dechlorination of 2,3,6-trichloropyridine with a conversion rate of 70.1 % and selectivity of 71.2 %. The catalyst showed outstanding catalysis performance even after five cycles. This simple and rapid one-pot strategy provides a new approach for the large-scale synthesis of efficient heterogeneous catalysts and offers an effective solution for reducing the high costs associated with precious metals. Graphical Abstract A novel strategy for one-pot synthesis of porous carbon nanospheres supported CuPd alloy catalysts for the hydrogenation-dechlorination of 2,3,6-trichloropyridine is reported for the first time. Keywords Bimetallic nanocatalyst CuPd alloy Porous carbon nanospheres Hydrogenation-dechlorination Heterogeneous catalysis Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction 2,3-dichloropyridine as a key raw material of the pesticide chlorantraniliprole is important for the development of next-generation pesticides. The selective hydrogenation-dechlorination of the 2,3,6-trichloropyridine to produce 2,3-dichloropyridine shows tremendous potential and development scope in production due to the advantages such as low raw material costs and a simple synthetic route [1]. However, the current industrial processes face significant challenges, including the high cost and low recovery rates of existing catalysts, particularly those based on Pd/C systems. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop efficient and stable catalysts for hydrogenation-dechlorination reactions. Addressing these challenges will help reduce production costs, improve sustainability, and enhance the industrial feasibility of next-generation pesticide production. Currently, research on selective hydrogenation-dechlorination reactions is mainly focused on Pd/C catalysts. For example, Zeng and Zhang groups [2] reported that the synthesized Pd/C catalysts can be used for the selective dechlorination of 2,3,6-trichloropyridine to synthesize 2,3-dichloropyridine with good conversion and selectivity. However, the reaction temperature is up to 140 °C and the Pd/C catalysts cannot be recovered. In addition, the high cost of Pd as a precious metal in the aforementioned Pd/C catalyst severely limits their applications. Therefore, it is advantageous to add a second component to reduce catalyst cost while improving its catalysis activity and stability. Several researchers have confirmed that bimetallic catalysts composed of alloys such as PdAg[3], PtCu [4,5], PdCu [6–8], etc., can selectively convert chloroalkanes to olefins with less or no chlorination. The changes in the selectivity of the hydrogenation-dechlorination show once again that the addition of a second metal to monometallic catalysts can significantly alter their activity and selectivity. Copper, as one of the transition metals, has advantages such as abundant terrestrial reserves, affordability and easy accessibility, and is therefore widely used in the construction of alloyed catalysts [9]. It is well known that the activity of heterogeneous catalysts strongly depends on the structure of the support. Recently, metallic oxide [10], zeolite [11], metal organic frameworks (MOFs) [12], covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [13], porous carbon materials [14–18] are recognized as attractive support candidates for the heterogeneous catalysts. Among them, the porous carbon materials have the advantages of their low skeleton density, low cost, easily modification of surface structure, and especially abundant pore structure, which make it the better choice as the support [19]. In particular, the phenolic resin polymer spheres plays a crucial role in the preparation of porous carbon nanospheres due to its high purity, well-defined pore structure, and favorable reproducibility [20]. Herein, we report a simple and efficient one-pot strategy for the large-scale synthesis of porous carbon nanospheres supported CuPd alloy catalysts using phenolic resin polymer spheres as precursors. Optimum catalyst performance can be achieved by adjusting the Cu/Pd ratio and the carbonization temperature. The obtained Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 exhibited excellent catalytic activity and high stability for the selective hydrogenation-dechlorination of 2,3,6-trichloropyridine to produce 2,3-dichloropyridine. Subsequently, the influence of reaction temperature, reaction time, hydrogen pressure, type and amount of binding acid, solvent and catalyst dosage on the catalytic performance was systematically investigated. This simple and rapid one-pot strategy provides a new approach for the large-scale synthesis of CuPd alloy nanoparticle heterogeneous catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials 3-Aminophenol (C6H7NO), Copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O), Palladium(II) acetate (Pd(OAc)2), 2,3,6-Trichloropyridine (C5H2Cl3N) and 2,3-Dichloropyridine (C5H3Cl2N) were purchased from, Adamas Reagent Ltd. Formaldehyde solution (CH2O, 35–40 % aqueous solution), Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30 %, w/w), Sodium carbonate (Na2CO3), Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3), Sodium acetate (CH3COONa), Triethylamine ((C2H5)3N), N,N-Diisopropylethylamine (C8H19N), Isopropanol ((CH3)2CHOH), Ethanol (C2H5OH), Methanol (CH3OH), 1,4-Dioxane (C4H8O2), N,N-Dimethylformamide ((CH3)2NCHO), Toluene (C6H5CH3), n-Butanol (C4H9OH), Cyclohexane (C6H12), Acetonitrile (CH3CN) and Acetone ((CH3)2CO) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd 2.2 Synthesis of catalyst 2.2.1 Synthesis of phenolic resin nanospheres (AFRNs) The AFRNs were fabricated according to the reported methods with some modifications [21]. Specifically, an aqueous-ethanol solution was prepared by mixing 168 mL of ethanol and 168 mL of distilled water in a 500 mL round bottom flask. Next, 1.467 g of 3-aminophenol was added while stirring under oil-bath heating at 30 °C until complete dissolution. Thirty minutes later, 2.5 mL of formaldehyde was added to the above mixture for polymerization for 1 h under continuous stirring at 30 ℃. Then, the reaction temperature was increased to 75 ℃ and the reaction system was stirred at 75 ℃ for 4 hours. The AFRNs were obtained by filtration and repeated washes with methanol several times. The AFRNs were rotated to remove the solvents and dried under vacuum at ambient temperature for 24 h. 2.2.2 Synthesis of carbon nanosphere-based heterogeneous catalysts loaded with CuPd alloy nanoparticles Cu and Pd ions were incorporated into AFRNs carriers via an impregnation method. Specifically, Cu(NO3)2∙3 H2O (10 wt%, relative to carrier mass) and Pd(OAc)2 (5 wt%) were dissolved in acetone and added to AFRNs carriers in a crucible under stirring at room temperature for 6 hours. The mixture in the crucible was then subjected to a tube furnace, maintained at 50 ℃ for 1 h under N2 atmosphere to remove the solvent. Subsequently, a heating rate of 2 ℃ min−1 to 500 ℃ was applied and held for 3 h, followed by natural cooling to room temperature. Specifically, 200 mg of the catalyst was dispersed in 10 mL of 30 % w/w H2O2 in a flask with a condenser for 3 h at 50 ℃, followed by washing with deionized water. The sample was then dried under vacuum at 60 ℃ for 24 hours. The resulting catalyst, labeled as "Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2". Similar catalysts with varying Cu/Pd loadings were synthesized following the same procedure, adjusting the amount of Cu(NO3)2∙3 H2O, such as by adding 5 wt% Cu(NO3)2∙3 H2O and 5 wt% Pd(OAc)2, or by adding 20 wt% Cu(NO3)2∙3 H2O and 5 wt% Pd(OAc)2. 2.2.3 Synthesis of carbon nanosphere-based heterogeneous catalysts loaded with CuPd alloy nanoparticles at different pyrolysis temperatures Three different ratios of Cu and Pd salts were used for further high-temperature pyrolytic reduction, and only the final carbonization temperature was changed to 800 ℃, while the other synthesis steps remained unchanged. 2.2.4 Synthesis of carbon nanosphere-based heterogeneous catalysts loaded with monometallic nanoparticles Using the above synthesis route only the type of metal salt added is changed, which were 10 wt% Cu(NO3)2∙3 H2O; 5 wt% Pd(OAc)2; 5 wt% RuCl3; 10 wt% Fe(NO3)3∙9 H2O; 10 wt% Ni(NO3)2; 10 wt%Co(NO3)2, and the rest of the experimental steps remained unchanged. 2.2.5 Synthesis of carbon nanosphere-based heterogeneous catalysts loaded with bimetallic nanoparticles Similarly, the above synthesis route of Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 was used by varying the type of metal salts added, which were 5 wt% Pd(OAc)2 and 10 wt% Fe(NO3)3∙9 H2O; 5 wt% Pd(OAc)2 and 10 wt% Co(NO3)2; 5 wt% Pd(OAc)2 and 10 wt% Ni(NO3)2, and all the other conditions were kept constant. 2.3 Catalyst performance testing Reactions in the batch reactor were carried out in a Teflon-lined (50 mL) stainless steel autoclave. As-prepared catalysts were loaded into the reactor with 3 mL solvent,1 mmol of acid acceptor and 0.5 mmol of 2,3,6-trichloropyridine. After being purged three times with purified H2 (99.999 % purity), and then charged with 1 atm of H2. The mixture was stirred in an oil bath at 80 ℃ with continuous stirring to react for 6 h. At the end of the reaction, it was cooled down to room temperature naturally and the residual H2 was released. After the reactions were carried out in organic solvents, the catalyst powder was removed by centrifugation. For the reactions in water, in consideration of insoluble substances in water phase, ethyl acetate was added into the liner to thoroughly extract organic products and the solid catalyst was removed by centrifugation. The extracted solution was mixed, condensed, and filtered through a membrane (0.22 μm) and a Shimadzu GC/MS system equipped with a Zebron ZB-1701 column was used for identification of products in the liquid mixture. All products were analyzed with a Tianmei 7900 GC instrument equipped with a flame ionization detector for quantification of the individual products. N2 was used as carrier gas. The response factors of each component were determined with standard samples, and the conversion of 2,3,6-trichloropyridine and the selectivity of 2,3-dichloropyridine were calculated. The definitions for the conversion rate of the product and its selectivity are as follows: (S1) Conversion = Mole of reatctant reacted Mole of reactant fed × 100 % (S2) Selectivity = Mole of product obtained Mole of reactant fed × 100 % 2.3.1 Catalyst recycling experiment For the recycling use of catalysts, the reaction mixture was separated by centrifugation at 10000 rpm for 10 mins. After washing with ethanol three times and drying, the precipitated catalysts were carried out the next run of catalysis. 2.4 Characterization Characterization of Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) and High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM). TEM and HAADF-STEM images were obtained using a JEOL JEM-2100F instrument working at 200 kV. Meanwhile, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping were also collected on the same equipment. Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) was collected with a field emission microscope (Zeiss Ultra 55) with an accelerating voltage of 5.0 kV. Samples were prepared by drop-casting one drop of the dilute sample solution onto a clear silicon wafer and the surface was sputter-coated with gold. Characterization of Powder X-ray Diffraction (XRD). The XRD patterns of the samples were collected using a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer, operating under conditions of 35 kV and 25 mA, with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5405 Å). Measurement of X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) and Auger Electron Spectroscopy (XAES). The XPS and XAES measurements were performed using the instrument of Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer, equipped with an Al Kα X-ray source. All acquired spectra were calibrated using the C 1 s peak from carbon contamination at 284.8 eV and analyzed using the XPS Peak41 software. N2 Adsorption and Desorption Experiment. The BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) specific surface area, N2 adsorption isotherms (77 K), and pore size distribution of the samples were determined using the Micromeritics ASAP 2460 surface area and pore size analyzer. BET specific surface area and micropore surface area were calculated using the BET equation and t-plot equation, respectively. The pore size distributions were analyzed by BJH methods via the adsorption branch. Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES) Testing. The Cu and Pd contents in different samples were determined with ICP-OES on the Optima 8300. Standard curve fitting was obtained by diluting the commercially available samples. Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA). TGA were carried out with a Mettler Toledo SDTA851e simultaneous thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 ℃ /min from 25 to 800 ℃ in a nitrogen atmosphere. Raman Spectroscopy Characterization. Raman spectra were collected on a Thermo DXR instrument using a laser excitation at λ= 532 nm. Gas Chromatography Characterization (GC). All gas chromatography results were obtained on the Tianmei 7900 gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization The preparation of Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 catalyst is shown in Fig. 1 a. With the help of AFRNs as a carrier, the acetone solutions of Cu(NO3)2∙3 H2O and Pd(OAc)2 were added and mixed thoroughly. After removal of the solvent, pyrolytic reduction was carried out to produce Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500. Finally, the catalyst was washed with H2O2 to remove the carbonaceous residue produced on the catalyst surface during the carbonization process [22]. The morphology and microstructure of the synthesized catalysts were characterized using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The SEM images confirmed that the APFNs precursors have the nanosphere morphology, and the synthesized Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 showed uniform carbon nanospheres and some metal nanoparticles on the surface of nanospheres (Fig. S1 ). The TEM images (Fig. 1 b and Fig. 1 c) showed that CuPd nanoparticles with an average particle size of about 10.5 nm are uniformly distributed in the porous carbon nanospheres. The distance between two adjacent lattice planes was measured to be approximately 2.2 Å in the high-resolution TEM (Fig. 1 d), closely matching the (111) crystal plane of the CuPd alloy [23]. The distribution of C, N, O, Cu and Pd was subsequently characterized using energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping (Fig. 1 e), and it can be seen from the images that Cu and Pd are uniformly distributed on the carbon nanospheres. To demonstrate the elemental valence and elemental composition of CuPd alloy nanoparticles, we used powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) to characterize the catalysts. As shown in Fig. S2, for the XRD patterns of the Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 catalyst, characteristic diffraction peaks with 2θ values of about 43.3° can be observed, corresponding to the crystalline reflections of Cu (111), respectively (Cu PDF #00–004–0836) [24].The characteristic diffraction peaks at 42.2°, 49.2°, and 72.2° are attributed to the (111), (200), and (220) reflections of Cu0.7Pd0.3, respectively (CuPd PDF #04–004–6535) [3]. Compared to the Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500 without H2O2 treatment, the XRD pattern of the Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 catalyst show more pronounced characteristic diffraction peaks for Cu and PdCu. This is because the H2O2 treatment removed the surface carbon layer, exposing the metal nanoparticles, which enhanced the intensity and clarity of the XRD signals. Subsequently, inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was employed to quantify the content of Cu and Pd in both Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 and Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500 catalysts. The results showed that the content of Cu and Pd in catalysts is almost no change after the H2O2 washing process. (Cu content of 1.72 wt% and Pd content of 2.1 wt% in Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2; Cu content of 1.65 wt% and Pd content of 2.09 wt% in Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500). The above evidence proves that CuPd alloy nanoparticles can be synthesized by high temperature pyrolysis and remain intact even after washing with H2O2. Then, we used XPS to further measure the surface elemental valency and elemental composition of Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 ( Fig. 2). The high resolution profiles of C 1 s for Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 were derived by Gaussian fitting and Shirley background deduction ( Fig. 2 b), and the fitted peaks were C-C (284.7 eV), C-O (286.2 eV), and CO (288.7 eV) respectively[25]. Simultaneously, the fitted peaks in the high-resolution spectrum of N 1 s (Fig. 2 c) corresponded to pyridinic N (398.6 eV), pyrrolic N (400.2 eV), and graphitic N (401.3 eV)[26]. The deconvolution of the O 1 s spectrum (Fig. 2 d) suggests the presence of oxygenated groups with three peaks: CO (531.4 eV), C-OH (532.9 eV), and COOH (534.4 eV)[27]. Moreover, the characteristic binding energy peaks at 932.2 eV and 952.2 eV in the Cu 2p high-resolution spectrum of the Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 catalyst (Fig. 2 e) can be observed, which may be due to the presence of Cu0/Cu+, while the characteristic peaks at 934.1 eV and 954.2 eV are characteristic of the presence of Cu2+ [28,29]. Meanwhile, the satellite peaks of Cu2+ can be observed at 941.5 eV and 962.0 eV[30]. Next, involving fitting of the Pd 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 spin-orbit orbitals (Fig. 2 f) elucidated the presence of both Pd0 and Pd2+ oxide states[31] within the catalyst. The generation of Cu oxide states (Cu+ and Cu2+) and Pd oxide states (Pd2+) within the Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 catalyst was attributed to the partial oxidation of surface CuPd alloy nanoparticles by generated O2 during the H2O2 washing process [32]. Finally, in order to distinguish between Cu0 and Cu+ more accurately, Cu LMM Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) was also measured ( Fig. 3). The asymmetric peak can be clearly divided into two fitting peaks, 569.9 eV and 573.0 eV, corresponding to Cu0 and Cu+, respectively[33]. According to the Cu LMM AES spectra, the molar ratio of Cu+/ (Cu0 + Cu+) is 0.31 in the Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 catalyst. This phenomenon suggests that Cu is not completely oxidized, but nanoparticles with multiple Cu valence states are generated, which may be attributed to the strong electronic interaction between Pd and Cu[34]. Subsequently, a comparison for the surface elemental content of untreated Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500 with Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 unveiled a substantial increase in O content and a decrease in C content, which is attributed to the increase in oxygen-containing groups on the catalyst surface and the removal of carbonaceous residues as a result of the H2O2 washing process (Fig. S3 and Table S1). Meanwhile, the Cu and Pd contents remained relatively stable. These data strongly substantiated the elevated presence of oxygenated groups on the catalyst surface, successful elimination of carbonaceous residues, and the sustained integrity of CuPd alloy nanoparticles after H2O2 post-treatment. The graphitization degree of the catalyst Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 was further characterized using Raman spectroscopy (Fig. S4). According to the calculated results, the intensity ratio (ID/IG) of the D and G bands was 1.12, indicating the presence of many defect structures on the surface of the carbon material. In addition, TGA curve showed that AFRNs precursor has good thermal stability and high residual carbon (∼ 59 %) at 800 °C (Fig. S5). The pore structure of the catalyst was measured by N2 adsorption/desorption analysis. It can be observed from the isothermal adsorption curve ( Fig. 4 ) that the isotherm is characterized by type IV adsorption isotherms, while conforming to type H1 hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of a certain number of mesopores in the catalyst. The BET specific surface area of the Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 catalyst was 284.5 m2/g and the pore volume was 0.17 cm3/g. The pore size distribution of BJH is known from the adsorption branching of the isotherms, and the results show that the pore size distribution of the catalyst is in the range of 2–20 nm, suggesting the formation of mesoporous pores with abundant pore sizes. 3.2 Catalytic performance investigation Firstly, we evaluated the catalytic performance of the above-prepared catalysts for selective hydrogenation-dechlorination of 2,3,6-trichloropyridine. As shown in Table 1 , the Pd/PCNs-500-H2O2 catalyst with monometal Pd nanoparticle exhibited excellent catalytic conversion rate (100 %) under the experimental conditions of 1 atm hydrogen and 80 °C with triethylamine (TEA) as the acid-binding agent, isopropanol (IPA) as the solvent, but selectivity is poor (32.7 %) (Entry 1). In addition, the conversion rate for commercial Pd/C was also 100 %, but the selectivity was only 29.7 % (Entry 11). Furthermore, the commercial Pd/C had significant metal leakage during the reaction. Other monometal nanoparticle catalysts, including Fe, Co, Ni, Cu and Ru, showed no catalytic activity (Entries 2–6). Subsequently, based on Pd nanoparticle catalysts, bimetallic nanoparticle catalysts were developed by combining non-noble metals. Among them, the catalyst Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2, composed of Pd and Cu, showed a conversion rate of 70.1 % and a selectivity of 71.2 % for 2,3-dichloropyridine (Entry 7). The introduction of Fe, Co and Ni elements into the bimetallic nanoparticle catalysts can increase conversion rate of the reaction, while their selectivity of 2,3-dichloropyridine will significantly reduce, respectively (Entries 8, 9 and 10). From the above data, it can be concluded that the incorporation of Cu into alloy nanoparticles effectively improved the selectivity of 2,3-dichloropyridine while maintaining a good conversion rate in the reaction. Based on the above results, further investigations were conducted on the catalytic performance of CuPd bimetallic nanoparticle catalysts prepared at different Cu/Pd weight ratios and different pyrolysis reduction temperatures. From the experimental data, it can be observed that under the same Cu/Pd metal salt addition conditions, catalysts prepared by pyrolysis reduction at 500 ℃ exhibited higher catalytic conversion rate than those prepared at 800 ℃ but the selectivity became worse. ( Table 2 , Entries 1,2,3 and 4,5,6).With 500 ℃ as the pyrolysis reduction temperature, as the loading of Cu in the catalyst increases, the catalytic conversion rate decreases from 100 % to 21.3 %, and the selectivity for 2,3-dichloropyridine increases from 25.2 % to 82.8 % (Entries 1–3).This may be due to the fact that introduction of Cu for CuPd bimetallic catalyst is effective in improving product selectivity. Among them, when the pyrolysis temperature is 500 ℃ and the weight ratio of Cu to Pd is 1.72:2.10, the catalyst shows the best catalytic performance with a conversion of 70.1 % and a selectivity of 71.2 % (Entry 2). In contrast, before H2O2 post-treatment, the Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500 catalyst exhibits negligible catalytic performance under the same conditions (Entries 2 and 7) due to the blocked active site of CuPd nanoparticles by a carbon layer formed during the pyrolysis process. In addition, the water dispersibility of the unwashed catalyst Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500 in the aqueous phase was much lower than that of Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 ( Fig. 5). Water contact angle measurements for both catalysts gave consistent results (contact angle for Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 was 30°, indicating hydrophilicity, whereas Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500 had a contact angle of 100°, indicating hydrophobicity). The above evidence suggests that H2O2 washing effectively removes carbonaceous residues on the catalyst surface, exposing more active sites, and also improves the hydrophilicity of the catalyst, leading to better dispersion in water and facilitating contact between substrates and active centers, thereby increasing mass transfer rates, which is consistent with our previous reports [14,35,36]. The influence of various factors on the catalytic activity in the selective dechlorination reaction of 2,3,6-trichloropyridine for the Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 catalyst was further discussed. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the influence of solvents with different polarities on the hydrogenation-dechlorination reaction was firstly investigated. It can be observed that the catalyst showed the good selective conversion of 2,3,6-trichloropyridine in strongly polar solvents such as water, ethanol, acetonitrile, isopropanol and n-butanol. No target product was produced in weakly polar solvents such as toluene and cyclohexane. This phenomenon is probably due to the excellent hydrophilicity and wettability of the Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 catalyst, which leads to a better dispersibility in these highly polar solvents, thus allowing a better contact between the substrate molecules and the catalytic active centers, ultimately improving the conversion rate of the reaction. The isopropanol as solvent was used to the following investigation due to the good catalytic performance. Because of the formation of hydrochloric acid by-products in this reaction, the addition of the acid-binding agent is essential to reduce the environmental impact. Different types of acid-binding agents can also affect the activity and selectivity of the dechlorination reaction. When inorganic salts such as sodium carbonate, sodium bicarbonate and sodium acetate are used as acid-binding agents, the conversion rates of the dechlorination reaction are all at relatively low levels (Fig. 6 b). This could be attributed to the poor solubility of inorganic salts in organic solvents, which prevents the hydrochloric acid from being neutralized in time and hinders the progress of the reaction. Under the same conditions, when triethylamine (TEA) and N, N-diisopropylethylamine were used as binding acids, TEA showed excellent catalytic efficiency (conversion of 70.1 % and selectivity of 71.2 %). Therefore, TEA was chosen as acid-binding agent for the following study. The influence of hydrogen pressure and reaction temperature on the conversion rate and selectivity of the dechlorination reaction was also investigated. Keeping other conditions constant and a reaction temperature of 80 ℃, gradually increasing the pressure of H2 in the reaction system from 1 atm to 3 MPa (Fig. 6 c) resulted in a slight improvement in the conversion rate with almost negligible changes in selectivity. This suggests that the pressure of H2 has a small effect on this reaction. Similarly, in a reaction system with 1 atm H2, simply changing the temperature of the oil bath (Fig. 6 d) showed that the reaction could not proceed at room temperature. As the reaction temperature increased from 40 ℃ to 80 ℃, the conversion rate increased from 12.3 % to 70.1 %. The selectivity remained at 100 % at 60 ℃, but decreased to 71.2 % at 80 ℃. This result indicates that increasing the temperature promotes the forward progression of the dechlorination reaction. At lower temperatures the reaction cannot be completed and at higher temperatures additional dechlorination by-products may be produced. The effects of the catalyst dosage and the amount of TEA on the selective dechlorination reaction were then further investigated. As shown in Fig. 7 a, as the catalyst dosage increased, the conversion rate of the dechlorination reaction increased from 29.3 % to 100 %. However, the selectivity for the target product, 2,3-dichloropyridine, decreased from 81.2 % to 37.9 %. These data suggest that as the catalyst dosage increases, the number of active sites in the reaction system also increases, which leads to more opportunities for substrate molecules to contact with the active centers, accelerating the progress of the reaction. However, the excessive catalyst dosage also affected the selectivity for the target product. Next, the effect of the amount of TEA as the acid-binding agent on the catalyst performance was evaluated (Fig. 7 b). With the substrate 2,3,6-trichloropyridine fixed at 0.5 mmol, under the same conditions, when the amount of TEA was only 0.5 mmol, the conversion was only 46.4 % with a selectivity of 82.9 %. This is probably due to an insufficient amount of TEA leading to incomplete neutralization of hydrochloric acid by-products in the system. When the amount of TEA was increased to 1 mmol, the conversion rate reached 70.1 % and the selectivity decreased to 71.2 %. Increasing the amount of TEA further to 2 mmol did not significantly improve the results compared to the 1 mmol condition. Clearly, using too much acid-binding agent does not effectively promote the dechlorination reaction. Finally, the progress of the selective dechlorination reaction of 2,3,6-trichloropyridine was monitored under optimum conditions (Fig. 7 c). Data were obtained for the same reaction system after 2, 4, 6 and 7 hours. As the reaction time increased, the conversion rate increased but the selectivity of 2,3-dichloropyridine decreased. Therefore, 6 hours is the optimal reaction time for the dechlorination reaction of 2,3,6-trichloropyridine. Finally, the cyclic stability of the Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 catalyst was tested. With a fixed reaction time of 2 hours, the reaction solution was separated by centrifugal separation after the reaction. The supernatant was filtered through a syringe filter (0.22 μm) and the conversion rate and selectivity for the target product, 2,3-dichloropyridine, were determined using a gas chromatography characterization (GC). The separated solid catalyst was washed three times with ethanol and dried for the next catalysis. As shown in Fig. 7 d, the catalytic performance of the catalyst remained stable even in the fifth catalytic cycle, demonstrating excellent cyclic stability. To further demonstrate its cyclic stability, we conducted a hot filtration experiment. After three hours of the hydrogenation-dechlorination reaction, we filtered out the catalyst, and GC analysis showed a conversion rate of 44.6 % for 2,3,6-trichloropyridine. Subsequently, the remaining 2,3,6-trichloropyridine in the liquid was subjected to the same conditions without any catalyst for an additional three hours, and GC analysis indicated that the remaining 2,3,6-trichloropyridine content was 45 %, suggesting that the conversion rate changed very little after the removal of the catalyst (Fig. S6). Therefore, the CuPd nanoparticles do not leach into the reaction system during the catalytic process. Additionally, ICP analysis of the residual liquid revealed almost no Pd or Cu present (less than 0.01 ppm), which is consistent with the leaching experiment results. This further highlights the stability advantages of the Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 catalyst developed in this study. The catalysts were then characterized by TEM, XRD and BET after several cycles to determine their integrity. According to the TEM images (Fig. S7), the catalyst retained its intact carbon nanosphere structure even after five cycles. The CuPd nanoparticles were still uniformly distributed in the carbon nanospheres without aggregation. Meanwhile, the XRD results (Fig. S8) showed that the characteristic diffraction peaks of the catalyst after five cycles were essentially identical to those of the fresh catalyst. The BET specific surface area of the catalyst remained at 302 m²/g after 5 cycles (Fig. S9), and the pore size distribution was roughly in the range of 2–5 nm, which was basically the same as that before cycling, with a slight decrease in pore size, which led to a slight increase in specific surface area, which is why the catalyst still had good catalytic performance after 5 cycles. This suggests that the oxidation states of the CuPd nanoparticles in the catalyst remained unchanged after multiple cycles, providing further evidence of the superior stability of the Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 catalyst. 4 Conclusions In summary, this study reports a large-scale synthesis of CuPd alloy nanoparticle heterogeneous catalysts, which were applied to the selective dechlorination reaction of 2,3,6-trichloropyridine. Using the optimal Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 as a catalyst, the effects of key factors such as temperature, solvent, H2 pressure, acid-blind agent types and their amounts on the selective hydrogenation-dechlorination reaction were systematically investigated. The synthesized Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 exhibited unique catalytic performance and excellent stability in selective dechlorination reactions. The experimental results provide a facile approach for the large-scale synthesis of bimetallic nanoparticle heterogeneous catalysts. Meanwhile, the catalytic performance of alloy nanoparticle catalysts with different Cu/Pd weight ratios in other multi-step conversion reactions (such as selective hydrogenation and selective oxidation reactions) awaits further investigation in future research. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogenation-dechlorination to produce 2,3-dichloropyridine is important for the next-generation pesticides. In this work, we successfully synthesized porous carbon nanospheres supported CuPd alloy nanoparticles via a simple and efficient one-pot strategy. Furthermore, by adjusting the Cu/Pd ratio and carbonization temperature, the obtained Cu2Pd1@PCNs-500-H2O2 showed the highly catalytic activity for the hydrogenation-dechlorination of 2,3,6-trichloropyridine with a conversion rate of 70.1 % and selectivity of 71.2 %. The catalyst showed outstanding catalysis performance even after five cycles. This simple and rapid one-pot strategy provides a new approach for the large-scale synthesis of efficient heterogeneous catalysts and offers an effective solution for reducing the high costs associated with precious metals.
